title: 2000 United States presidential election
added: In contrast to the South realigning to the Republican Party, the 2000 presidential election also helped mark the realignment of much of the [[Western United States]], particularly the [[West Coast of the United States|West Coast]], to the Democratic Party. Gore narrowly carried Oregon and New Mexico, the latter of which was actually closer in raw votes than Florida.

Oregon would continue to vote Democratic in subsequent presidential elections, while New Mexico would vote for Bush in [[2004 United States presidential election|2004]] before subsequently only voting Democratic.

title: 2000 United States presidential election
added: Bush won both [[Nevada]] and [[Arizona]]. This election was the last time Nevada voted for the popular vote loser, with the state voting otherwise for the popular vote winner in every 21st century presidential election, the current longest streak of any U.S. state. Arizona would stay Republican except in 2020, when it voted for [[Joe Biden]].

title: 2000 United States presidential election
added: This election was the first in which non-college whites were significantly more Republican than college-educated whites, although both groups voted for Bush. Bush also made large gains with Hispanic voters, and he would do even better among them in 2004.

Gore did well with African American voters, although it was not enough to win any Southern states. Gore also did marginally improve among college-educated White women, which foreshadowed Democratic strength with this demographic in future years.<ref name="A Detailed Look Back"/>

title: 2000 United States presidential election
deleted: Trump won [[Pennsylvania]] in 2016 and 2024 but not 2020. Pennsylvania was the [[tipping-point state]] in both of Trump's victories.

title: 2000 United States presidential election
deleted: Income polarization significantly shrank among voters, although it still remained high. Income polarization would not be eliminated until the Trump era.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/education-not-income-predicted-who-would-vote-for-trump/|title=Education, Not Income, Predicted Who Would Vote For Trump|date=November 22, 2016|access-date=January 13, 2025|website=FiveThirtyEight|first1=Nate|last1=Silver}}</ref><ref name="culture trumps economic class">{{Cite web |title=How culture trumps economic class as the new political fault line|date=March 28, 2024|website=Silver Bulletin|access-date=January 13, 2025|first1=Nate|last1=Silver|url=https://www.natesilver.net/p/how-culture-trumps-economic-class}}</ref>
